title: Pitches from companies
segmentation: Good morning everyone.
Yeah, I think you have my heart, my name now many times so I was saying that I'm basing Netherlands working for Croda.
Kroda is an English company.
And yeah, we are operating globally.
I think like Evonik, you might not know Crowder 'cause we are also more as a additive supplier to big companies which at the end it can be using wall panes or in automotive or.
Impersonal care, so maybe maybe some of you are using L'Oreal or.
Nivea, or some product from PNG and the most important component that gives the active.
Actually, functionality that comes from Crowder.
So basically we have everything like ivanick but much better.
Now, well, Votic is a little bit bigger than Crowder.
But as you have seen, we close that we came first with antimicrobial technology.
So mostly, we added the trendsetter and they never look follow.
Well, so you have heard a lot about.
Already this technology?
Yeah, this is a contact active.
Coding what we are creating here.
How it works is that we make this kind of polymers cationic polymers.

And the idea is that this polymer is then bound in a matrix of another problem that in that way you prevent leaching from the coating and our knowledge is also in mainly to make sure that this polymer always migrate to the surface, because it will only work when is at the surface.
Alright.
Maybe quickly how the technology works.
Many of you already know how micro cell looks like.
They have a cell membrane.
They have phospholipids and those phospholipids are negatively charged.
Group containing that negative charge group so that will interact with a positive charge surface.
This is a physical adhesion force and then you have the hydrophobic tails that interact with the hydrophobic part of the cell membrane.
So the cell membrane get in stress.
Because of that, two different adhesion force and that is why they would not like the surface and will die naturally.
Alright.
OK, you know already this picture, this is a nice test method to show the different working mechanism.
So here you see already that if you don't use any bio side the pain will be attached by mold.
The middle one is if you use our leachable Biosite you will see that the paint is protected but also you see a zone of inhibition.
That means that the Biosite was released to the Agar plate.
And then if you don't use any little bias that you see that the only the paint surface is protected, not around this paint.
So this is our lab tests as someone was saying.
I think what is more impressive, what we did is using Japanese standard method and.
Using a standard washing method.
To see how long the efficacy will be there.
So what you do is actually making a paint of your of your technology and put it in the water for four hours, and it allows you to that all components can reach out and you dry it.
And you tested the antimicrobial efficacy.
So what we did is for example against C simulants.
And we compared with some other competitor technologies like IPC.
We see that IPC for example.
Is already not effective to bacteria at all.
As you might know already that everything above location 2 is antimicrobial and four is strong antimicrobial, right?
An IP season organic Biosite.
We test also think pretty on which is also well recognized in the market.
Also, here we see that initially it was very effective.
It has a lock reduction more than five, but just after three times washing the activity decreased.
Dramatically actually with self assault, almost the same case in beginning was effective, but after just 2 three times, watching the activity decreased.
Then you have another interesting technology as well, where the those organic biocides are encapsulated.
So like a sync pretty on IPC, an oot nice names.
But they are done encapsulated in the particles an then we see that indeed because of Incapsula shun the efficacy is much better than compared to the others.
But eventually, also after 9 times washing, the efficiency was lost.
Well, what micro fans?
Which is our technology you see as is non leaching, after even 15 times washing there is no activity last.
So challenge these tests with your other technologies.
We did the same test now with mold aspects also here IPP.
This time IPC works better in against mold, so not against bacteria.
We also actually mult you.
Don't test it with the Japanese test method, but just to compare it.
We use state with the Japanese test method.
Yeah so with IPCC.
Initially good efficacy, but after just 2 three times watching the efficacy was lost.
Sing pretty on almost the same case.
Silver is not even against mold, so.
I am, I hope I'm all find some efficiency against mold, but the test we have seen was not effective against mold.
Again, the encapsulated Biosite initially shows very good performance but also leached out quickly.
Not surprised micro fans didn't lose its efficacy after even 515 times watching again.
So our main target today is also selling this technology.
More environments where you want to prevent biofilm.
So for example, in facade marked to prevent algae growth.
And then you can see with this technology after you know more.
It will be effective for long time than compared to the traditional biocides.
Or in bathrooms against mold.
I have also used independent Institute in Netherlands TNL everybody knows?
It's it's compatible to two in Germany, but.
They also do the antimicrobial test.
We so we checked it also whether it is effective against other bacteria, then only one type.
So it is.
Also against something is so it's not only against one type of microorganism, but really against wide range of microorganism.
Well, the challenge I think it's now already many times set that the legislation is a big challenge.
It's all the time changing and the big issue is I guess the authorities are also doesn't know really what they want.
So we are all the time discussing with the authorities.
Yeah, well what needs to be registered?
How can we prove it?
And at the end, how can we reject it in such a way that we can sell it?
You have seen numbers of millions.
It is true it costs millions, so it's not very cheap registration.
And as Simona also said.
After you rejected the product, you also need to sell it so that is what the authorities.
Don't understand, of course.
They only take that you have to register it, but you need to get our return of investment as.
As you are going to, yeah, you're spending a lot of money and you need still to sell it at will.
Also take a time.
So it's the biggest obstacle to actually sell this technology in or actually, antimicrobial coatings in hospitals.
And also I've mentioned, which I think is also a big obstacle.
Is there is no really good measurement how you show the efficacy in the real life.
So we have a lot of lab tests.
And definitely with bacteria which you don't see with your eyes, you want to do it with still swaps or with some measurement methods that you hope that are correct.
And I think that also the goal why you want to use antimicrobial coatings is not really set clear.
So for example, we are talking about decreasing the infection.
In the hospitals, but how do you prove that?
So.
We are going to use the antimicrobial coating.
What you are going to prove is well, if you don't use antimicrobial coating you see more bacteria growth on that surface.
That's it.
What does that mean really?
After that that it also will.
Decrease infection in hospitals or not.
So I think the it's very unclear really.
The adding value actually in the antimicrobial coating hospitals which needs still to be investigated.
And.
Yeah, that needs more research to show.
The benefit of the coding, so that's why we are not at the moment in the health care facilities.
I think that's it.
Thank you for your time.
